column3: Pennace at the chapel of the Espiración
column5: The chapel to which Don Juan Manuel was sent as penance for accidentally murdering his nephew on a nighly murderous walk. Despite repeated attempts, Don Juan Manuel struggles to complete his penance due to haunting voices and the sound of a bell, finally culminating in his death found hanging at the gallows.

column3: Legend of the Obedient Dead Nun (Site)
column5: After her death, Sor Teresa, a tall and devout nun from the convent of Santa Brígida, miraculously complied with an order to fit into a coffin that was too short for her, proving her obedience even in death. On the eve of a major festival, the Mother Superior commanded Sor Teresa to adjust within her coffin, and before all, she did so, her feet pulling back with a sanctified little bang, allowing her to be buried in peace.

column3: Legend of the Puente del Clérigo (site)
column5: Don Duarte de Sarraza, murdered his lovers protective uncle, priest Don Juan de Nava, but was mysteriously killed a year later on the same bridge by a skeleton dressed in a cleric's cassock. The skeleton, believed to be the ghost of Don Juan, exacted revenge on Don Duarte with a dagger still lodged in its skull, revealing the truth of the priest's murder to the town.

column3: Miracle of the Altar del Perdon
column5: Don Simon Peyrens, once a notorious sinner, miraculously painted the finest image of Our Lady of Mercy after a divine intervention by the Virgin herself while imprisoned for blasphemy in Mexico. His heartfelt transformation led to his absolution and the picture, originally painted on his cell door, became the centerpiece of the Altar del Perdon, forever altering his fate and earning him reverence and freedom.

column3: Legend of the Aduana de Santo Domingo
column5: Don Juan Gutiérrez Rubín de Celis, known for his laziness, was transformed by his love for Doña Sara de García Somera y Acuña, accepting her challenge to complete the long-delayed construction of the Aduana de Santo Domingo in six months to prove his worth as a husband. Driven by his infatuation, Don Juan showed unprecedented energy, organizing resources and labor with such effectiveness that he completed the task ahead of schedule, leading Doña Sara to marry him.

column3: The street of the Burn Woman
column5: Tihis street was once known as the street of the burn woman as, hundreds of years ago Doña Beatrice de Espinosa, a young and beautiful woman, fearing that her lover, Don Martín Scipoli, was drawn to her merely for her looks, drastically disfigured herself by burning her face with coals. The story does have a happy ending...

In an old tale, a blacksmith unknowingly shods iron shoes to a mule that was actually the transformed housekeeper of his friend, a priest, leading to her death through mysterious divine retribution. Upon discovery of the terrible truth, the priest disappears forever and the blacksmith is left haunted by his actions for the rest of his life.

The story centers around a bell cursed by devils and evil origins, including its creation from devil-forged armor worn by a wicked knight, Don Gil de Marcadante, who vanished mysteriously after being imprisoned by the Inquisition. The cursed bell, after terrorizing a town near Madrid by ringing itself furiously, is exiled to Mexico, where it becomes a clock bell in the Palace, remaining unused until melted by the French during the Intervention, with its metal allegedly turning sour.

On a rainy night, Padre Lanchitas is called by an old woman to hear the confession of a dying man, who claims to have been dead for centuries and committed terrible crimes before dying unconfessed. Although the notary later asserts that the house where the encounter took place has been long abandoned, Lanchitas finds his handkerchief inside, confirming the eerie experience and the absolution given to a soul from hell.

In 1593, a Spanish soldier named Gil Pérez mysteriously appeared in Mexico City's Plaza Mayor, claiming to have just been in Manila guarding the Governor's Palace, despite being dressed in a Manila palace guard's uniform not recognized locally. His story, stating the recent assassination of the Governor of the Filipinas, was eventually confirmed with the arrival of news from a galleon, leading to his release and ordered return to Manila, despite his unexplained seeming alliance with the devil being suspected by the authorities.

column3: Legend of the Calle de la Joya
column5: Don Alonso Fernández de Bobadilla discovered a letter accusing his wife, Doña Ysabel, of infidelity with Licenciado Don José Raul de Lara and, in a fit of rage, murdered both of them with a dagger. To proclaim his actions, he pinned the golden bracelet he found on Ysabel's wrist to the door with the bloody dagger, leading to the street being named Calle de la Joya.

column3: Legend of the Calle de la Machincuepa (approx)
column5: Doña Paz de Quiroga, niece of the wealthy Marqués del Valle Salado, must perform a public somersault, called a 'machincuepa', in the Plaza Mayor to inherit her uncle's riches, as per his peculiar will. Despite her pride and rigorous elegance, she complies with the condition, facing the shame intended by her late uncle, and the street is thereafter named Calle de la Machincuepa after her act.
Intriguing fragments of folklore include a leather 'fairy-apron', a legend that foretells the fall of the castle and, an underground passage that is said to connect with Edenderry Castle.
A very scant (but arguably verifiable) snippet of folklore states that water continuously drips from the upper tower while there is an heir to the chieftainship of O’Donovan.

Visitors and locals have long claimed that Howth Castle is touched by the supernatural, from the mysterious “Tristram Tree” said to guarantee an heir to the house, to the spectral rat that reappears as an omen of misfortune. Tales of vanished strangers, prophetic tokens, and uncanny animal guardians lend the ancient fortress a lasting air of paranormal intrigue.
Lea Castle is now a very atmospheric ruin. No grass grows where a dual ended in two deaths, and if that wasn't enough, there is also a cursed well.

Prince Bladud, afflicted with leprosy, discovered the hot springs near Bath when his pigs rolled in the hot mud and were cured of their skin diseases. Cured himself, Bladud built a city at the site of his healing, which became known as Bath, a city famed for its healing waters even before the Romans popularized it as Aquæ Sulis.

Guy, Earl of Warwick, known for his valorous deeds, including the defeat of a giant and the legendary Dun Cow, chose to live a life of solitude disguised as a hermit near his home in Warwick. Before his death, he sent his wedding ring to Lady Phyllis, who joined him in his final moments, marking a poignant close to their story, which echoes through the halls of Warwick's heritage.

Wayland Smith, believed to be a deity related to Thor, settled in Pagan England and eventually took up a blacksmith's trade, offering to shoe horses for a silver penny at a remote cave near the ancient Ridgeway in the Berkshire Downs. Though few people visit now, it's said that if you follow the correct procedure, you might still have your horse shod by the legendary smith for a sixpence.

In the dead of night, a village nurse was taken under mysterious circumstances to a manor where she witnessed a masked man kill a newborn baby, only to later realize that the incident was real when she discovered a grim token from the scene. The manor was identified as Littlecote, and "Wild Darrell, " believed responsible for the heinous crime, escaped death through bribery but could not escape the spectral hauntings that led to his own untimely end.

Bronwen, a British princess, was married to the Irish king Matholwch, but after a series of insults and mistreatment, she was relegated to being a cook in his palace. Unable to communicate her plight to her brother Bran due to interference from the Irish, Bronwen ingeniously sent a message via a starling, prompting Bran to launch a rescue mission which led to a tragic battle where Bran died, and Bronwen survived him only briefly before passing away, broken-hearted.

In Carnarvonshire, North Wales, a village girl named Grace neglected her duty of covering the well she tended, leading to a flood that created Llyn Glasfryn, and as a punishment, she was transformed into a swan, doomed to swim the lake until the Day of Judgment. The region, full of legends and historic tales, is also known for its scenic beauty, from its dramatic coastlines to its mountains, attracting sportsmen, artists, and those seeking tranquillity.

Ezekiel Grosse, an avaricious attorney who obtained Rosewarne through shady means, was haunted by a ghostly figure promising gold, leading him to great wealth but eventual isolation and misery due to the spectre's persistent presence at his gatherings. In the end, Ezekiel was forced to give up his wealth to his clerk to rid himself of the ghost, which ultimately led to his lonely death, allegedly attended by demons at his funeral.

A parson known for his violent temper became lost on a stormy night while journeying to visit a dying bishop at Dawlish, guided by his parish clerk. After a night of revelry with mysterious companions at the behest of a stranger guide, the parson and clerk were transformed into rocks off the Dawlish coast, legend attributing this to their encounter with demons.

Drake's friendly demon magically transformed wood chips into gunboats to help him defend against the Spanish Armada. The demon also sped up the construction of Buckland Abbey's outbuildings, startling a servant who observed the spectral builders.

The legendary lost land of Lyonesse, reputedly a fertile region extending from Cornwall to the Scillies, was submerged by the sea during a devastating storm in 1099, leaving behind only the Scilly Islands and the rocky remains known as the Seven Stones. According to tradition, this land gradually succumbed to the sea, with its final inundation being documented in tales of survivors like Trevilian, who narrowly escaped on horseback, and is remembered through stories of submerged villages and relics sometimes caught in fishermen’s nets.

column3: The Stone Men of St. Cleer
column5: In ancient time, the people of St. Cleer were so fervent about their traditional game of Hurling that they neglected their Sunday church services, prompting the local saint to transform those who defied him into standing stones, known as "The Hurlers, " still visible today on Craddock Moor. This transformation served as a permanent symbol of the consequences of impiety, casting a timeless reminder within the wild, expansive landscapes of Cornwall.

Tregeagle, once an evil man of Cornwall, finds himself condemned to endless torment after his death by performing impossible tasks set by Churchmen to save his soul from demons. His tasks include emptying Dozmary Pool with a perforated shell, spinning sand ropes, and moving sands between beaches, all of which are reset by natural forces or demon intervention, ensuring his perpetual struggle near Cornwall's rugged coasts.

A cowherd from near Llandovery falls in love with a beautiful lady who emerges from Llyn-y-Fan-Fach, and she agrees to marry him under the condition that he must never strike her thrice without cause. Years later, after the third inadvertent blow, she leaves, returning to the lake with their livestock, and their sons grow up to be famous doctors thanks to her mystical influence.

A legend from the neighborhood of Bala Lake, Merionethshire, tells of the original town that once thrived where the lake is now, which was engulfed by water due to the unchecked overflow of a well after its guardian neglected to cover it. The lake, now five miles long, is believed to continue growing, eventually threatening to overtake the new Bala and the village of Llanfor, as the spirit of the well remains unappeased.

column3: A Case of a Mara in Jutland
column5: Near a village in Jutland, reapers found a seemingly asleep naked woman under a hedge, whom a shepherd identified as a mara with plans to ride someone that night. After a small creature entered her mouth, the woman sprang to life, leaped a bush, and vanished without a trace.

Nielsen, plagued by horrific nightmares, follows Osdeven's advice to sleep with a knife, leading to a terrifying encounter with the mara, Christine Jansen, who vanishes upon contact with the blade. The evidence of blood confirms his experience, and after Christine's sudden illness forces her abroad, his nightmares cease, leading him and Osdeven to vow caution in future relationships.

column3: Spirit of a Living Man Throwing Stones
column5: John Stephens encountered a living man's spirit throwing stones as he walked home one evening in Llanarth, Cardiganshire. This unusual phenomenon was confirmed by other accounts of living spirits, sometimes heard but not seen.

column3: Death Portents and Phantom Funerals in Wales
column5: In the Welsh village of Ffynnonddagrau, the old man Thomas Harries was known for his uncanny ability to predict deaths, including those of local residents like John Thomas and Rassie of Moelfre Fach. His predictions were so accurate that people were wary of encountering him, fearing his prophetic insights into impending mortalities.

A young man from the Gwaun Valley witnessed a phantom funeral, which eerily mirrored an actual funeral three days later when his friend passed away. The vision left him so frightened that he was afraid to go out at night, prompting a visit from the storyteller and a clergyman to confirm the account.

column3: An Old Woman Who Saw the Apparition of Her Own Funeral
column5: An old woman with the gift of second sight saw a vision of her own funeral procession on a road leading to Caersalem Chapel, noting specific details about the participants. Shortly after, she died and the real funeral occurred exactly as she had envisioned, confirming her premonition to the community.

Thomas Jones recounts how a local witch was feared for cursing those she disliked, including bewitching a neighbor's horse for trespassing. The animal was cured only after a conjurer from Llangurig was consulted, highlighting the local belief in these supernatural remedies.

Mrs. Mary Thomas from Bengal near Fishguard recalled that it was customary to protect against witches by burning a mare's heart filled with pins and nails, with the smoke directing towards the witch's dwelling. Similarly, an old woman recounted that a suspected witch had to leave the district, but when livestock continued to fall ill, a cow's heart was burnt to compel the witch to return and heal them.

A Pembrokeshire woman named Mrs. Evans, known for her prophetic visions, predicted seeing a series of autonomous, fast-moving carts in Trefgarn Valley, which locals later interpreted as a foretelling of a railway line that was ultimately constructed nearly 100 years later. Despite setbacks and ridicule when initial railway projects bypassed the area, a new line was eventually built exactly as Evans had envisioned, fulfilling her long-dismissed prophecy.

Evan Morris from Goginan near Aberystwyth used written charms from a conjurer to cure bewitched animals, such as a sow, by rubbing the paper over their backs while reciting a Christian prayer. Mr. Hamer noted that these charms included various religious invocations, symbols, and the word 'Abracadabra', and were believed to protect livestock from witchcraft and evil influences when kept near them.

A young lady who developed fits after a frightful encounter with lightning was cured by ingesting pills made from a dead man's bone. The bone was sourced from Llanwnda Churchyard and ground into powder for the remedy.

A local tradition in Carmarthenshire tells of a small well with a stone cover on a hill near Gorslas that turned into the lake known as Llyn Llechwen due to a boy failing to replace the cover. An alternative version of the tale attributes the incident to a warrior named Owen Lawgoch and his men, who supposedly sleep in a cave waiting to be awakened by the sound of battle.

The village of St. David's in Pembrokeshire is home to the Talking Stone Llechlafar, which is said to have spoken when a corpse was carried over it, and other mystical stones, including steps that ring like bells and the Expanding Stone that adapts to the size of whoever enters it. These stones share similarities with mythical stones from Welsh tales, such as the ring of Gyges, highlighting a rich tradition of folklore involving magical stones with unique powers.

A man from Tirup owned a mare with a Nis that brought him luck and secretly fed his animals with stolen corn. When a new owner sold the mare, he lost his prosperity as the luck followed the mare, but the new owner lost the Nis's favor by spying, equalizing fortunes again.

The story describes the mythical origin of the Nine-hills near Rambin, said to have been created by the spills from a Giant's apron as he attempted to connect the island of Rügen to the mainland. Alongside tales of giants, it tells of Dwarfs inhabiting these hills, specifically the White and Brown ones, who live along the coast and are known for holding assemblies and plundering wrecked ships.

In Hessian folklore, the Still-people, or Dwarfs, inhabit secretive spaces in the mountains of Plesse, living in chambers filled with gold and gemstones while aiding those who win their favor. These beings remain hidden from the world, surfacing only at night due to their vulnerability to sunlight, with abilities such as invisibility and passing through solid objects.

At a wedding celebration in the village of Glass, near the Wunderberg, a Hill-man joined the festivities, danced gracefully, and rewarded the guests and bridal party with unknown coins, advising them to live humbly and charitably. After enjoying the hospitality, he was ferried across the river Satzach by a boatman, whom he gifted magical protection from drowning and urged to live a pious life, before departing abruptly.

In the vicinity of Dardesheim, a magical spring flows from a hill inhabited by helpful dwarfs who loan festive attire and utensils to the locals. In return, the dwarfs are content with just a share of the festival's feast left at the hill.

column3: Journey of the Dwarfs over the Mountain
column5: In the valley between Blenkenburg and Quedlinburg, a baker discovered that his missing loaves were being stolen by Dwarfs, prompting a series of events that led to their departure from the region. To compensate for their theft, the Dwarfs filled a cask with ancient coins before leaving, marking the end of their presence in the area.

A midwife from the village of Walchwyl helped the queen of the Dwarfs give birth and was gifted what seemed like black coals which turned out to be precious stones. Despite her initial disappointment and discarding most of the coals, the two she retained turned into valuable jewels, leaving her to regret her hasty actions.

The Reverend Charles Bunworth, a well-respected rector in Buttevant, was known for his benevolent nature and support of itinerant harpers, earning their gratitude and fame beyond his local parish. In the week leading to his death, eerie sounds attributed to the Banshee were heard near his home, foretelling his passing; despite skepticism, several credible witnesses confirmed these ominous occurrences around the time of his demise.

The arrival and stay of a small family of dwarfs at the village of Pik-mik-tal-ik left a significant cultural impact on the villagers, introducing innovative sled designs and burial practices. The dwarf father's remarkable strength, friendly nature, and the tragic death of his son led to changes in local customs, while sightings of dwarf people persist in the area, embodying their lasting legend.

A young cowherd named Michael, called the Star Gazer, follows a dream to a castle where he uncovers the secret of twelve princesses who wear out their shoes each night dancing with enchanted princes. Through magical assistance, Michael discovers their hidden midnight revelries and eventually wins the heart of the youngest princess, Lina, becoming a prince himself.

In Eritrean folklore, Anderebo is a mysterious night creature said to hurl massive stones onto rooftops after sundown, only to vanish by morning. The sight of the stones left behind made this tale one of the most frightening stories told to children in Asmara.
A monster which lived in a cave and protected the Matsuyama Castle.
A Witch or 'evil woman' in the folklore of the Mari people (Russia)
A species of giant mosquitoe in the African-American folk tradition.
A spook or monster which appears in old or uninhabited houses.
A humanoid cryptid that appears as a giant and wears a mushroom-like hat. Associated with the disappearance and death of cattle.

Jimmy Squarefoot is a peaceful, pig-headed creature with boar-like tusks and squarish feet wrapped in calico. Once said to be ridden by the stone-throwing Foawr giants, he now wanders the Isle of Man’s countryside.
The Cheval Mallet is a sinister horse from French folklore, said to lure weary travelers at night with its striking appearance and then spirit them away, often never to return.
Lou Drapé is a folkloric horse, said to abduct children at night. Likely linked to the drac legend of Occitania
Aunt Arie, a benevolent fairy, serves as a Christmas figure in place of Santa Claus or Saint Nicholas.

The Borda is a fearsome witch-like figure, spelling trouble those who encounter her on foggy nights or near marshlands. Serving as a personification of the dangers of swamps, her legend was often used to scare children and keep them away from hazardous waters.
A Brazilian folktale about an enslaved boy who becomes a spirit guide.

A mythical figure who visits homes in October to ensure families have adequately prepared for the challenging month, with the tradition of preparing jopará, a local dish, serving as a symbolic safeguard against his curse.

A chilling legend from Colombia and Venezuela, depicting a cursed spirit doomed to wander the countryside carrying his father's bones, known for his eerie whistle that serves as a forewarning of death.

column3: Lady Meng Jiang and the Great Wall
column5: Lady Meng Jiang is a Chinese folktale about a woman whose husband was forced to build the Great Wall and died there; her grief caused part of the Wall to collapse.
The story follows Xi Xuanzan, who falls for a woman revealed to be a white snake; a Daoist exorcist subdues her under three pagodas in West Lake.

The legend of Liang Shanbo and Zhu Yingtai, set in the Eastern Jin dynasty, tells of Zhu disguising herself as a man to study and befriending Liang, who remains unaware of her true identity. After their love is thwarted by an arranged marriage, Liang dies of heartbreak, and Zhu joins him in death, transforming into butterflies symbolizing eternal love.

column3: The Cowherd and the Weaver Girl (across China)
column5: Written in the stars - this Chinese folktale tells of the forbidden love between Zhinü, a weaver girl, and Niulang, a cowherd, who are separated by the Milky Way and can only reunite once a year on the seventh day of the seventh lunar month when magpies form a bridge across the sky.

The Hane no haeta kappa is a breed of yōkai that has features resembling chickens or pheasants, including clawed bird-like hind legs and long hair-like feathers covering its body. It inhabits wetlands such as ponds, marshes, and swamps, and while not typically aggressive towards humans, can be dangerous to those who enter its territory.

Hinnagami are powerful spirits from Toyama Prefecture that reside in dolls and grant their owners' wishes. However, they demand constant requests and attachment to their creators, often haunting them even after death.

Ichimoku nyūdō is the guardian of Lake Kamo, a water god with a large, single eye on his head. According to legend, he was once punished by humans for taking fish from their willow tree and now annually attacks homes and temples on the same day as a form of revenge.

Iso onna are dangerous vampires from the Kyūshū islands and Western Japan, known for preying on fisherman and travelers. They appear as beautiful women who have just come out of the water, but have an otherworldly nature that allows them to transform into rocks or attack with their long hair.

Itsuki are malevolent spirits that haunt the living to drive them to suicide. They inhabit the underworld and take on the form of ghosts who died by hanging, seeking to replace themselves in the afterlife by coercing others to kill themselves.

Kanibito is a crab-like yōkai with human female features who resides in the ocean and possesses the ability to speak. It is known for delivering prophetic messages to humanity by calling out to people on shore, often waiting days for someone brave enough to approach it.

Kosamebō is a yōkai that appears as a Buddhist monk, typically on empty mountain roads at night during light rain. They accost travelers and beg for alms, such as spare change or food, without posing any real danger to humans.

Maikubi are a trio of severed samurai heads that float on the surface of the sea around Sagami Bay at night. Driven solely by anger, they dance in circles, bite each other, and spit flames from their mouths, bringing bad luck and increasing the risk of shipwrecks and sea disasters.
A beautiful pool said to be haunted by a maiden who drowned there. Legend claims her spirit lingers, occasionally causing eerie silences.

Aka Shita is a mysterious spirit that takes the form of a dark cloud with sharp claws and a hairy, bestial face. It appears during summer months to punish farmers who steal water from their neighbors, using its long, bright red tongue to drain their fields.

With its origin at one of the cities schools - the Akateko is a Japanese yokai that appears as a red, disembodied child's hand hanging in Japanese honey locust trees. It is known to drop down from trees and surprise passersby, although it does not cause significant harm beyond giving them a fright.

Akuru is a monstrous fish from Japanese mythology that appears in the country's oldest mythological texts. It is described as a giant fish or evil god, capable of swallowing a ship whole, and was said to have been slain by the legendary warrior prince Yamato Takeru.
Amemasu is a Japanese yōkai that appears as a white-spotted char fish or a beautiful woman with cold clammy skin, capable of transforming and consuming humans.
Amemasu is a Japanese yōkai that appears as a white-spotted char fish or a beautiful woman with cold clammy skin, capable of transforming and consuming humans.

Atuikakura is an enormous sea cucumber that lives deep in Uchiura Bay in Hokkaido, Japan. It is a scavenger that occasionally eats ships and can be very dangerous when startled, thrashing about wildly and capsizing or smashing vessels.

Azuki babā is an old hag yōkai from Northeast Japan that appears in forests and villages at twilight on rainy nights, singing a husky voice and threatening to catch and eat humans. Her song is similar to the azuki arai's, but with a sinister twist, and she is often seen as a shape-shifted evil itachi, tanuki, or kitsune imitating the harmless azuki arai.

Bake ichō no sei are the tall, bright yellow spirits of very old ginkgo trees that wear tattered black kimono and carry small gongs. They strike their mallets, causing those who hear them to feel strange or shocked, although it's unclear what purpose this serves.
The Bakekujira is a Japanese yōkai described as an animated whale skeleton. It is said to haunt coastal whaling villages, rising from the sea and bringing disasters such as famine, plague, and fires.

Basan is a rare, nocturnal bird found only on the island of Shikoku in Japan's Ehime mountains. It has distinctive bright red plumage, a long tongue-like flame-like breath that flows from its mouth, and makes a unique 'basabasa' sound with its wings.

Bashō no sei are spirits of Japanese banana trees (Musa basjoo) native to the Ryūkyū archipelago. These spirits, which appear as human faces amidst broad banana leaves, are not typically hostile but can be frightening and may even lead to dire consequences if encountered under certain circumstances.

The Bitan is a large, chubby, cow-like sea creature from Okinawan folklore that lives in the waters around Taketomi Island. It has magical healing properties and its image can allegedly cure headaches when hung on a wall.

The Botamochi Bakemono is a yōkai from Japanese folklore that mimics voices by copying sounds coming from underneath floorboards. It gets its name from botamochi, a traditional sweet made from sticky rice and brown azuki paste, and is known for pranking people by repeating their words.

Furaribi is a small, flying creature wreathed in flames that appears late at night near riverbanks. It is said to be created from the remains of a soul that has not properly passed on to the next life due to lack of ceremonial services.
Furutsubaki no rei is a type of yōkai from Japanese folklore. It is believed to be the spirit of an old tsubaki tree, which has the ability to bewitch and trick humans.

column3: Bowscale Tarn - home to 2 immortal fish
Peg Powler aka the High Green Ghost
column5: The High Green Ghost—Peg Powler of the River Tees—is said to have lived in the valley now flooded by Cow Green Reservoir and to haunt the waters around Mickleton and Middleton-in-Teesdale, her green hair and tell-tale “suds” revealing her presence. Local lore warns that in this peaceful corner of County Durham she can still lure the unwary into the cold depths with her long arms and sharp claws.
A folkloric horse that has its own festival. Every 10 years, four consecutive brothers are chosen to ride an effigy of the giant horse.
A monster or giant - having a single eye, hand and foot.

Mishipeshu, or the underwater panther, is a powerful mythical being from the traditions of Indigenous peoples. With the form of a giant cat covered in scales and spikes, it is regarded as the master of water creatures and a prominent figure in both mythology and ceremonial symbolism.
Gelert is a legendary Welsh hound associated with the village of Beddgelert, whose tragic story revolves around a misunderstood act of heroism defending a child from a wolf.

The Dodomeki is a cursed woman demon from Japanese folklore, characterized by having long arms covered in tiny bird eyes. According to legend, she was once a human girl who developed a penchant for stealing money, and as punishment, her arms transformed into the bird-eyed monster.

Eritategoromo is a yokai that resembles a Buddhist priest's kimono with a long, pointed nose and eyes. It was once the worn-out kimono of Sōjōbō, King of the Tengu, who transformed from a human high priest into a demonic tengu.

The Garappa is a regional corruption of kappa, found only on the island of Kyushu in southern Japan. It resembles a kappa but has longer limbs, a more streamlined face, and distinctive calls of 'hyō hyō' or 'foon foon foon', and is known for its mischievous behavior, strength, and sexual aggression.

The Hakutaku is a wise, chimerical beast resembling a white ox with nine eyes and six horns. It is said to be a good omen, symbolizing good luck and possessing great knowledge about all things in creation.
Hari onago is a yōkai from Japanese folklore known as Hook Girl. She appears at night in Shikoku, targeting young men with her hook-like hair and brutal attacks.

Hitokai is a prophetic sea creature from Japanese folklore that has the appearance of a human woman with a snake-like body, long black hair, and a third eye in its forehead. It resides in a conch shell and glows in five different colors at night, delivering important messages or prophecies to humanity when it appears offshore.

Hōsōgyo is a type of Japanese yokai that resembles a shrimp but has a head like a shōjō, faces like a horse or cat, and four fins resembling arms and legs. They are found in eastern Japan's oceans and coastal areas, spending their days swimming and emerging at night to roam on land.

The Hyōsube is a squat, hairy humanoid creature found primarily on Kyūshū and in West Japan. It has a malicious smile and sharp teeth, prefers to eat eggplant, and is known for its belligerent and violent behavior.

Ibaraki dōji is a legendary Japanese demon known for wreaking havoc on the human world and serving as the chief deputy to the powerful oni Shuten dōji. Depicted as either male or female, Ibaraki dōji was a fearsome monster who could be seen haunting areas like Rashōmon gate in Kyoto.

Ittan momen is a type of Japanese yōkai that takes the form of long, narrow sheets of cloth. Native to Kagoshima, these reanimated fabrics can be seen flying through the sky at night and attack by strangling or smothering their victims.

Iwana bōzu are yōkai that appear as enormous char fish, dressed in Buddhist priest robes, and lecture humans on the importance of refraining from excessive fishing. They target people who use cruel or unnecessary methods of fishing, such as poisoning rivers, and often transform into human shape to interact with humans.

Kaijin are humanoid, aquatic yokai who live in the sea, with a human-like appearance, flippers instead of hands and feet, and spotted skin that resembles a skirt. They possess a human level of intelligence but have difficulty communicating with humans and can only survive for short periods out of water.

Kappa musume are female water spirits from Japanese folklore that disguise themselves as young human women. They typically inhabit villages near rivers or lakes, and their interactions with humans often involve seeking food while trying to blend in.

Kasha is a type of Japanese yokai (supernatural creature) that appears as a large, bipedal feline with hellish flames or lightning accompanying it. This monstrous cat, often disguised as an ordinary house cat or stray, feeds on fresh human corpses and is known for snatching bodies from coffins during funeral services.

The Kawa Akago is a yōkai that resembles a small, red-skinned baby. It tricks victims by mimicking the sound of crying human babies and then attacks them when they approach to comfort it, often leading to accidental drowning.

Kenmun are hairy water and tree spirits that inhabit the Amami islands in southern Japan. They have the ability to change shape, create light and fire, and possess supernatural strength when their head-dish is filled.

Kijimunā are elfin creatures that inhabit banyan trees on the islands of Okinawa in Japan. They have a humanoid lifestyle, with a preference for seafood and a strong dislike for octopuses and certain human behaviors.

Kiyo hime is a demon woman from Japanese literature who appears in The Legend of Anchin and Kiyo hime, an ancient tale from Wakayama prefecture. She is often depicted as the antagonist who transforms into a giant, fire-breathing serpent after being spurned by a young priest named Anchin.
Koromodako is a terrifying octopus-like yōkai from Japanese folklore. It can grow to enormous sizes when threatened, engulfing fish, fishermen, and even entire ships in its massive, cloth-like body.

Kōjin is an aquatic humanoid creature from Japanese folklore that resembles a shark or ningyo, with black scaly body and ugly human-like facial features. It is said to live in the South China Sea, where it spends its time weaving high-quality sea silk and crying tears of precious gems.
Kanibōzu is a yōkai, a mischievous spirit in Japanese folklore. It appears as a giant crab that disguises itself as a priest and haunts temples, often demanding riddles from visitors.
Houses, made by man... for elves.

The Lee Penny is a medieval Scottish amulet consisting of a dark red stone set in a silver coin, long kept by the Lockhart family of Lee. Traditionally believed to heal illnesses in people and animals—often by dipping it in water—it became one of Scotland’s most famous medicinal talismans.

A woman from Wildmore was believed to have a snake living inside her, and attempts to lure it out with milk failed until she eventually died. The tale hints at fears of hidden illness and Christian symbolism that equated the serpent with evil within the body

King Cnut is said to have tried to halt the tidal wave called the Trent Aegir near Gainsborough, mixing Viking history with myth despite the story being unlikely. The Aegir itself inspired older customs like throwing silver into the water and may preserve traces of pre-Christian belief

Debauched monks at Crowland Abbey were warned by a demonic apparition that destruction was coming, and a year later Viking raiders slew the abbot and his brethren. A skull said to be the abbot’s became a relic, tying the massacre to later legends of divine punishment and the Devil’s prophecy

The moon descends to the Carrs, becomes trapped by bogles and will-o-the-wisps, and vanishes from the sky until locals follow a wise woman’s guidance to free her. Once released, she shines brighter than ever, keeping the night terrors at bay
A mysterious boulder was said either to disgorge a drake or dragon from quicksand or to sit atop a demon-guarded treasure cave, resisting all attempts to move it

A mischievous hob-thrust secretly helps a farmer with his chores in exchange for a fine linen shirt each year, but when the farmer downgrades to a coarse sackcloth one, the hob disappears and the farm’s fortunes sour. The tale shows how a temperamental household sprite can bring prosperity—or mischief—depending on how it’s treated

A tiny demon-child arrives on a wicked wind to cause havoc in Lincoln Cathedral, only to be frozen into stone by holy power. The “Lincoln Imp” stays perched there forever, becoming a beloved symbol of the city and its mischief

column3: The Lad Who Looked for Fools
column5: A young man balks at marrying into a foolish family until he finds three even bigger fools—shoveling sunshine, sawing rocks, and hauling cows onto roofs—proving his bride’s kin are no worse than most. He marries her in the end, and the supposed peril of the garden well proves no peril at all

A tiny seal-faced boggart was said to paddle across a bend of the Trent in a pie-dish boat, sneak into fields, and nibble the crops, causing locals to avoid the spot. Later retellings turned the creature into a comic, fish-smelling suitor who tries—and fails—to woo a modern woman

column3: Oswald and the Shaft of Light
column5: When King Oswald’s relics were left outside Bardney Abbey as “foreign, ” a heavenly beam of light shone from the cart through the night. Shamed, the monks welcomed the relics and vowed never to shut their doors again—giving rise to the local saying for anyone who leaves a door open: “Do you come from Bardney

A girl goes to a woodland spring called Nanny Rutt’s Well to meet her sweetheart, but instead encounters an old shawl-covered woman who kills her and leaves her body by the well. Ever after, the place is said to be haunted by Nanny Rutt, and children warn one another never to go to the well alone

A simple lad asks a wisewoman how to become clever, and she tells him he’ll know more than she does once he wears a “coat o’ clay.” Taking her literally, he rolls in mud and dust to make one, never grasping that she meant the shroud of the grave

A man digging on Langrick Fen unearthed a skeleton with a wolf’s head and took it home, only for a werewolf-like beast to break in that night and prowl the rooms until dawn. Terrified, he reburied the body at Dogdyke and the creature was never seen again—at least not by him

column3: The Farmer and the Boggart in Mumby
column5: A crafty farmer repeatedly outwits a greedy boggart who demands half his crops—first letting the creature choose “tops” while he plants potatoes, then “bottoms” while he sows wheat, and finally slowing him with hidden iron rods in a reaping contest. Beaten three times, the boggart gives up the land and goes back to scaring folk and pinching their supper

A farmer seeks help from the cunning man Fiddler Fynes to find who robbed him; Fynes shows him a mirror in which the culprit’s face appears, and when the glass is cracked the thief is marked with the same cut next morning. Confronted—and forgiven—the man returns what he stole, sealing Fynes’s reputation as a wiseman
Children with wings, a wisewoman, multiple murders, no summary can capture this bizarre tale

Warning - this tale contains serious overreaction! Fred is hired by a farmer for being cheap to feed, but his greed leads the farmer to beat and mutilate him after repeated thefts. After Fred fails to keep watch and the hayricks burn, the enraged farmer throws him into the fire and kills him

Villagers in Burgh le Marsh tried to wreck ships for plunder, but during a storm a sexton named Guymer locked himself in the church and rang the great bell to warn a passing vessel away. When the villagers finally broke in they found him dead with the bell still moving, and the saved ship’s captain later married his daughter

A sea captain named Grim and his ally Boundel steal two magic stones from the Danish king, but the stones nearly sink their ship and can only be carried by the pair. After the stones grow too heavy to deliver to King Lud, locals discover that striking them with hazel brings rain and flourishing crops

column3: All Saints' Church and the Holbeach Gamesters
column5: Three friends in Holbeach dug up a recently deceased companion and took his body into the church so they could play cards with him. Folklore later claimed that demons carried the gamblers off and that ghostly lights still flicker in the church at night

A farm labourer is told that the coffin passing by contains his wife, even though he saw her healthy hours earlier, so he insists it be taken home and finds her seemingly dead inside. In the night she suddenly revives and, after asking for water, goes on to live a long life with him

A lazy farmhand frees a tiny boggart named Yallery Brown from under a rock, and in return the creature promises help so long as it is never thanked. Yallery’s mischief quickly ruins the lad’s life, and in some tellings he ends up cursed forever

column3: St Andrew's Church, Stainfield, and the Wild Man
column5: A wild man was said to haunt the woods near Stainfield, stealing livestock and terrorizing locals until he was hunted down and killed. His memory lives on in carvings and relics in Stainfield’s church

A man entered a supposed underground passage between Kirkstead Abbey and Tattershall Castle with his dog and a bugle, promising to sound it if he was in trouble; after the dog fled and vanished and the bugle grew fainter, the man was never seen again. The “tunnel” was later understood to have been an old sewage canal from the Abbey

Mr Lacy gives all his goods to his three sons on condition they care for him in turns, but they soon neglect and mistreat him. Pretending to have a hidden fortune, he wins back their kindness, then before dying returns the borrowed money and forgives them

Tom Hickathrift was a mighty, super-strong hero famed for battling giants and performing great feats around the Fens. His adventures were told across Norfolk, Cambridgeshire, and the Lincolnshire border, and he became a legendary giant-killer in local lore

Tiddy Mun was a tiny bearded sprite who could make floodwaters rise or fall, and villagers called on him for help during high water. When the Fens were drained and his home damaged, misfortune swept the land until people apologised to Tiddy Mun with water at the new moon, after which prosperity returned

column3: John Smith and the Church Tower
column5: John Smith was famed for downing twelve half-pints at noon, but when he lost a drinking contest he was tricked into climbing Louth’s church steeple for a wager. The seller vanished with the winnings, leaving Smith to pay the bill and earning him the nickname “Ten-Pint Smith.

A kindly shepherd is warned by a magician that a great flood is coming, so he climbs the church tower with his best sheep and tolls the bell to save who he can. A tidal wave then engulfs the hamlet for three days, and when the waters finally recede most of the place is gone

A ferryman on Read’s Island was said to have murdered and eaten his passengers until, when finally put on trial, he transformed into a wolf. Hundreds of bones were claimed to have been found on the island, sealing his reputation as the Read’s Island Werewolf

column3: The Lass that Saw Her Own Grave Dug
column5: Bessie dreams of danger and hides in a tree at the spot where her sweetheart Fox asked her to meet him, and watches as he digs her grave. When she later reveals what she saw in a riddle, he tries to flee but is seized and taken away

A shaggy, glowing-eyed creature called the Lackey Causey Calf was said to appear between Wrawby and Brigg and lure travellers toward a stream, sometimes even without a head. Such “shag foals, ” kin to will-o-the-wisps, were once widely reported across the region before their sightings faded awa

Tom Pattison ignores all warnings about spirits on the Carrs and is dragged away by a disembodied hand in the dark, later found alive but mutilated and doomed to die in terror. After his death he haunts the place with his mother, serving as a warning to the reckless and unbelieving

In 1906 a night-mail train roared through Grantham without stopping and crashed, killing all aboard, and no one ever learned why. Rumours and eerie witness accounts—drivers staring ahead, men fighting in the cab, or sudden illness—turned the unexplained disaster into a modern folk mystery

Legend says that if you run three times around Markby’s thatched church at midnight and hammer a nail into the door, a ghost will appear. The custom was widespread enough that the old church door is pitted with nails said to come from such attempts

A loyal servant at Girsby Manor warned his master about a gang of robbers who had threatened to flay him unless he helped them, leading to the gang’s capture and execution. Later tales claim the servant mysteriously vanished while travelling past the gibbets that held the robbers’ bodies

Gainsthorpe is one of Lincolnshire’s best-preserved deserted medieval villages, and local legend claims it was once a den of robbers destroyed and burned by neighbouring villagers. A more detailed oral version recounts how a man uncovered the gang’s crimes, raised a militia, and the entire village was razed to the ground

The Stamford bull-run was a centuries-long local tradition in which a bull was chased through the town each year, later remembered through a legendary origin story involving William de Warenne witnessing bulls fighting for a cow. The colourful tale of how the tradition began is almost certainly mythic, but it survives as the folk explanation for a real — and notoriously brutal — ritual that lasted until its ban in 1839

Tabshag was the nickname of a nineteenth-century squatter who lived beside the ruined Tower on the Moor, keeping pigs in its upper level and harvesting plover eggs from the surrounding boglands to sell in London. His odd lifestyle and outsider status led some locals to treat him almost like a bogle or uncanny figure, a reputation later picked up in song and local lore

column3: Th' Lad 'at Wantid to Larn to Shuther an' Shak
column5: A lad who has never felt fear decides he wants to learn what it is. He spends three nights in a haunted mill, where strange creatures and boggarts appear — among them a huge Black Dog and a wild Tatterfoal-like horse. Instead of panicking, he calmly deals with each apparition and refuses to be frightened. After the third night he wins the miller’s daughter as his reward, but still hasn’t truly learned how to shudder

A sixteenth-century family tomb at Bigby features a carved “wild man” figure linked to the Tyrwhitts, thought to have inspired the later legend of the Wild Man of Stainfield. The sculpture’s imagery—wild men bearing clubs and a brood of children—suggests strength and lineage, giving a possible folkloric origin for the East Midlands’ best-known wild man tale

Ciapek, a stray dog adopted by Polish airmen at RAF Ingham, flew eight missions as the squadron’s mascot and co-pilot. Shot down on the ninth, he miraculously washed ashore alive and was reunited with his crew, becoming a symbol of loyalty and resilience

Cavalum is a fire-breathing, winged-horse-shaped demon of local folklore whose storm-born screams are said to roll out of the caves over Machico’s valley. In legend he once challenged God and was imprisoned in these caves.
